info.game_comments:
Second game in which reigning champion did not return.
Alex returns from a full knee replacement, stays at his lectern during the contestant interviews, and uses a cane during the closing credits chat.

(2, 1).clue: Once in hiding, he began a book tour in 2015 for his novel "Two Years Eight Months and Twenty-Eight Nights"

(3, 1).clue: This word of measure can precede "bird" "-of-ale" & "stick"

(4, 1).clue: This actress who played Satine in "Moulin Rouge!" was actually born in Honolulu

(5, 1).clue: To talk a lot, especially in order to persuade someone, isn't "to mandible" but this synonym

(6, 1).clue: Winky tells this boy wizard, "House-elves is not supposed to have fun...house-elves does what they is told"

(2, 2).clue: On December 7, 1941 this Tarzan creator was playing tennis with his son in Honolulu when Pearl Harbor was attacked

(3, 2).clue: A 4-inch tall horse would measure one of these, & be very hard to ride

(4, 2).clue: A surprise about this original "Mad Max": He was born in Peekskill, New York

(5, 2).clue: The first cervical vertebra is called this after a Greek god because it supports the head

(6, 2).clue: In TV commercials, Buckets the elf is in charge of splashing fudge on this brand's cookies

(2, 3).clue: Thomas Hardy set most of his books in rural areas, as suggested in the title "Far From" this throng

(3, 3).clue: This word found before "of women Voters" is also a distance of about 3 miles

(4, 3).clue: At my signal unleash your response of this Wellington, New Zealand-born actor & Oscar winner

(5, 3).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew shows an X-ray illustration on the monitor.)  Falling on an outstretched arm is the most common cause of a broken wrist, & it's often this forearm bone, which is closer to the thumb, that is fractured

(6, 3).clue: Azari is a fire elf & Naida a water elf in this Danish company's toy line & accompanying media franchise

(2, 4).clue: In 1992, this "Hotel New Hampshire" author, once a college wrestler, was inducted into the Natl. Wrestling Hall of Fame

(3, 4).clue: Someone drunk is "in his" these, though in his pints is more like it

(4, 4).clue: "You're the One That I Want" hit No. 1 in 1978 for John Travolta & this Cambridge, England-born woman

(5, 4).clue: This area behind the brain stem is involved in the coordination of voluntary motor movement

(6, 4).clue: Tolkien would have said "Who the heck is Tauriel?", the wood elf played by this actress--she was created for the "Hobbit" films

(2, 5).clue: She says that "Mama" & "How Stella Got Her Groove Back" are her most autobiographical novels

(3, 5).clue: After you land at the airport, pick up your car at this unit of frequency counter

(4, 5).clue: The British Isles was the birthplace of the Disco kings of the '70s, this band of brothers

(5, 5).clue: The thyroid gland has 2 lobes, one on each side of this tube

(6, 5).clue: In a Grimm tale, the wife of this artisan made clothes for the elves to show her gratitude for making them rich

(1, 1).clue: The Russian people suffered greatly during the war & blamed this czar who was forced off the throne in early 1917

(3, 1).clue: This first gospel contains Jesus' words, "Bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you"

(5, 1).clue: This fabric used in coats usually comes from the Bactrian type

(6, 1).clue: How square! In the mid-'80s this "amazing" puzzle showed off its colors on its own cartoon series

(1, 2).clue: The May 8, 1915 headline in the N.Y. Times blared this ship "sunk by a submarine... twice torpedoed off Irish coast"

(2, 2).clue: This word means operating disconnected from an associated computer

(3, 2).clue: In a preface to this book, Walt Whitman urged people to "despise riches" & "hate tyrants"

(5, 2).clue: A fabric made from this tall grass is all the rage in part due to its antibacterial properties

(6, 2).clue: This video game was based on a Japanese folk hero known for his voracious appetite

(1, 3).clue: The Zimmerman Note encouraged this nation to ally with Germany, which promised to let it annex lost land in the U.S.

(2, 3).clue: Hey, dummy! The healthiest way to be hanged is "in" this way

(3, 3).clue: In a 1981 movie this actor declares, "I hate snakes"

(4, 3).clue: You can visit the city of Bowling Green & the state university of the same name; they're both in this state

(5, 3).clue: This lace named for a town in France was paired in song with "a pretty face and a ponytail hanging down"

(6, 3).clue: He's seen here in a current photo, but he remembers the '80s when he was a TV & music heartthrob

(1, 4).clue: On July 4, 1917 this AEF leader marched his troops through Paris to lay a wreath on the tomb of Lafayette

(2, 4).clue: It's a written declaration upon oath made before an official

(3, 4).clue: Congress says this 2-word phrase is an "offense involving actual or perceived race, color, religion", etc.

(4, 4).clue: For more than 40 years, Edison worked in this town with both a direction & a color

(5, 4).clue: This woven fabric used for suits sounds like a poetic contraction referencing the future

(6, 4).clue: As this "Wall Street" corporate raider, Michael Douglas taught us that greed is good

(1, 5).clue: The Allies suffered around 250,000 casualties trying unsuccessfully to reopen this strait also known as the Hellespont

(2, 5).clue: It's an iron hook with a handle for landing big fish

(3, 5).clue: In this Shakespeare play, Viola says "I hate ingratitude more in a man than lying, vainness", etc.

(4, 5).clue: This Alabama college town's name was inspired by a line from Oliver Goldsmith's poem "The Deserted Village"

(5, 5).clue: Sails & beach umbrella are 2 items traditionally made of this hempen or flaxen cloth

(6, 5).clue: Miles Davis so loved the melody of her hit "Time After Time", he recorded an instrumental version

(0, 0).clue: In 1927 the publishers of the Modern Library widened its scope and took this name, meant as a joke about how it would select titles
